author: gdr36
title: Year of the Rat
review: I got this set from buying the Hogwarts Express at the LEGO store a few months ago. Its box is very special and it has a card inside the box because the idea is that you give it to someone as a gift. It is an interesting build, and most of the rat's limbs are on ball joints, which makes it very poseable. The coolest piece used was the elephant tusk piece as the rat's tail. The rat is cuter in real life than in pictures and is a good display piece. However, it has no features, it is only for putting on a shelf. Overall, a good promo worth the eighty dollars spent to get it.

author: Odeinoichus
title: Zodiac New Years Sets are Impressive.
review:
Set #40355 Year of the Rat: In January of 2020 this set was offered as a free gift with purchase and it is highly impressive. This is my first time with one of these Chinese Zodiac based sets and I must admit I was quite impressed with it. And I will attempt to articulate why with this review.

Packaging

A very impressive package design, a small square pop-open type reminiscent of LEGO Sets bygone past, you can pop the flap open to find a small tray to store the parts and manual when finished with the built model. The front has a To/From sticker design printed on, this name tag element is meant to hold names when given as a gift.

The image on the front shows the set, includes the name across it and a large NEW above it. The back shows off certain features and a pile of parts involved in the build.

The manual is a nice thick looking rectangular design with very well put together pages allowing for easy to follow build steps. A parts list on the back and that’s about it. There is also a special envelope inside of a nice thick card stock with a very impressive looking gold embossed representation on the back of this envelope. Noting is inside of it, I believe this is meant to hold a small card when giving this set as a gift.

Parts

A fairly standard selection of bricks and plates and other unique elements make up the bulk of the pieces in this set. A few printed eye tiles are included, nothing very special, but I’m certain many will enjoy finding uses for these parts if they have more than one Year of the Rat in their collection.

The build

Somewhat similar to a BrickHeadz this build creates a model rat using LEGO bricks, including a lot of bricks with side studs during the process will see some similarities, but overall this build is a bit more involved and impressive for the finished product looks nothing like a BrickHead while using a few similar techniques to it. Really impressed with this build, found it thoroughly engaging.

The completed model

With ball jointed ears and paws and a tail that can swivel around thanks to the Technic Pin connection, this Rat model is highly impressive. He can spin his head too. As a unique set it’s highly collectible too, but honestly I am just all around impressed with how they designed and pulled off making a cute almost cartoon inspired rat model.

Overall opinion

I can be far too positive at times. But that’s because I just love LEGO so much, it’s inventive, clever, creative and fun to collect and build. It’s also great fun to discuss and point out aspects of a set I find enjoyable. This set represents the Chinese Zodiac and is a very impressive design. It also uses SNOT design very effectively to limit the number of visible studs. I enjoyed this set and would recommend it if you also enjoy sets of this style and function. If you prefer to collect the latest Ninjago or Star Wars set it’s definitely safe to skip this. This is more designed to be a display piece rather than something to build and play with. It compliments past Chinese Zodiac sets quite well too, so if you managed to get them there’s no reason not to get this one.

Recommended for fans.
